intro: Haplopappus cuneatus, commonly known as the narrowleaf horsebrush, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive leaf morphology. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought and poor soil conditions. Its leaves are narrow and linear, often with a bluish-gray hue, and it produces small yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. Haplopappus cuneatus is often found in sagebrush communities and is an important component of its ecological habitat.
